items.title: Remove extra > tag added by previous "nit fix"

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Content-Type doesn't make sense for requests without bodies. Accept is likely what the author intended.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it

I have seen this error being made twice in production code and it's possible MDN was the cause. Setting the Content-Type header for a GET request can also lead to an unnecessary CORS preflight request.
items.title: Replace `Content-Type` with `Accept` in `fetch` GET examples with headers

items.content_html:
This PR removes 89 live samples from the https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/appearance page. They formed a "Demo" column in the two big "Values" tables, but didn't seem to show anything.

There was also an empty column in the "Obsolete values table - I thought of removing this column but on reflection just removed the whole table, borrowing the content removal policy in BCD: https://github.com/mdn/browser-compat-data/blob/main/docs/data-guidelines.md#removal-of-irrelevant-features .
items.title: Remove live samples from the "appearance" page

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Over in BCD, we're inclined to drop Accept-Charset. Browsers haven't sent this header for many, many years (IE since 2008, Chrome since 2013). After giving it some thought, I think mentioning in this decade confuses more than informs. Some text I removed makes a pretty good case for me:

With UTF-8 now being well-supported, being the preferred way of encoding characters, and to guarantee better privacy through less configuration-based entropy, browsers omit the Accept-Charset header: Internet Explorer 8, Safari 5, Opera 11, Firefox 10 and Chrome 27 have abandoned this header.

Nobody ought to send this header, servers ought to ignore it, and it's interesting mostly as a historic artifact. This PR scrubs most mentions of the header (except as one of the forbidden header names) and deletes the reference page.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Accept-Charset
items.title: Remove mentions of historic `Accept-Charset` header

items.content_html:
Before:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ParentNode/replaceChildren

After:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/replaceChildren
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/replaceChildren
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DocumentFragment/replaceChildren

IDL:

interface mixin ParentNode {
  [CEReactions, Unscopable] undefined replaceChildren((Node or DOMString)... nodes);
};
Document includes ParentNode;
DocumentFragment includes ParentNode;
Element includes ParentNode;
items.title: Demix Parentnode.replaceChildren to Element, Document, DocumentFragment pages

items.content_html:
Add a page for WebHID API. Later I will add pull requests one by one for the global interfaces HID, HIDConnectionEvent, HIDInputReportEvent, HIDDevice.

As for compat data, already added a pull request: mdn/browser-compat-data#9910

And it seems the backend didn't recognize the correct specification url, it should be: https://wicg.github.io/webhid/ . So maybe ur backend developers should work to fix that recognization problem?
items.title: Add a page for WebHID API

items.content_html:
This is the last of the Background Fetch interfaces.

Reviewer @jpmedley
items.title: Adds BackgroundFetchUpdateUIEvent

items.content_html:
If we’re going to mention CSRF in the CORS article, we would need to say quite a lot more than what this note says. And since this note is wrongly saying that you don’t need to worry at all about CSRF in a specific subset of cases (simple requests), it may give the very wrong impression that CORS overall doesn’t create any additional CSRF risk.

So it’s better to mention nothing at all about CSRF in this CORS article than it is to have this one mention in this one odd note.

Fixes #4111
items.title: Drop unhelpful note about CSRF from CORS doc

items.content_html:
mdn/yari#3530 adds support for having specific text in the {{AvailableInWorkers}} macro. This updates the "common macros" page with the change, and also uses it in the XMLHttpRequest page.

This won't be ready to merge until the change gets into content repo. Creating so I don't forget.
items.title: AvailableInWorkers supports replacement text
